5 Reasons why your New Year’s resolutions won’t work

by Jake Snow on 04.06.2020

Share

Starting the new year off with a few personal changes in mind always seem logical.

It’s a new year, a new decade, full of infinite opportunities for self-growth and self-development. These changes also go by the name New Year’s Resolutions. Come February, and you’ve probably forgotten about most of them.

Here’s 5 reasons why New Year’s resolutions never survive the first month:

  1. Your resolutions or goals are just to big and unrealistic to achieve
  2. Your resolutions are not actually yours. They are your perception of what you should change based on social media and the influence of other people
  3. You are not motivated or determined enough to follow through on your resolution
  4. You don’t have a practical plan to achieve your resolution
  5. You believe you will fail before you even try

Is this really your true goal? Ask yourself if you want to do this

So, what can you do differently this year to implement change in your life? It is actually easier than you think. It all starts with something small. Rather than setting a big unrealistic goal for yourself, break it down in smaller goals that can help you move towards your bigger end goal. Time management is also important. Even if you begin small, you consciously need to make time to get used to your new habit or behavioural pattern.

Let’s say you would like to start exercising every day and follow a plant-based diet. If you jump right in with two hour gym sessions when you’ve never done exercise in your life, followed by going vegan immediately, you will only end up with a stiff body, lacking energy and probably even some stomach troubles because of the drastic change in diet. If your new goals are making you feel bad, why continue with them?

Rather start small, taking into consideration time and budget. Start with planning thirty minutes of your day with mild exercise like walking, swimming or a Pilates class. Even if you manage just three times a week, that’s still better than giving up. Analyse your progress after a month and then add on to your thirty-minute habit. Science have shown that linking a new habit to an existing good habit has a better chance of success. You can even link your exercise goal with your plant-based goal, i.e. after every workout session I will drink a smoothie or eat a vegan buddha bowl – no animal-based proteins.

If you want your New Year’s resolutions and goals to succeed keep this in mind:

  • Is this really your true goal? Ask yourself if you want to do this
  • Break it down into smaller manageable chunks
  • Manage your time
  • Pair new habits with old ones that are working for you
  • Surround yourself with like-minded people who encourage your goals

This year try to make a real change by starting off small. 

Eyes of a Nomad.
